issues.description: The solution's ExcellenceLand constructor parameter order (List<Ride> rides, boolean excellentEnough, double excellencyLevel) does not follow the constructor-order rule from the problem statement. The UML lists ExcellenceLand attributes in the order: excellencyLevel (double), excellentEnough (boolean) and the task text additionally requires a private rides attribute of type List<Ride>. The exercise explicitly requires constructors to take attributes in the same order as in the UML (first attribute on top => first constructor parameter). The current solution reverses that order which conflicts with the specification and would confuse students about the expected constructor signature and cause automated checks to fail.
issues.suggested_fix: Reorder the ExcellenceLand constructor parameters to match the UML attribute order. A consistent and clear signature would be: public ExcellenceLand(double excellencyLevel, boolean excellentEnough, List<Ride> rides) { ... } and assign the fields accordingly (this.excellencyLevel = excellencyLevel; this.excellentEnough = excellentEnough; this.rides = rides;). This preserves the educational requirement that constructor parameters follow the UML ordering and avoids confusion or failing tests.
